default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 33, 152</bibl></cit>.—With an <pos>adj.</pos>: <cit><quote lang="la">multum loquaces,</quote> <trans><tr>very talkative</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 2, 1, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mepti labores,</quote> <trans><tr>very</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:1:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 1, 9</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg> also with <hi rend="ital">comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">multum improbiores sunt quam a primo credidi,</quote> <trans><tr>much, far</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:3:2:139" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 3, 2, 139</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">multum robustior illo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:19:197" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 19, 197</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">majora,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:13:708" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 13, 708</bibl></cit>.— <cb n="MULT" /> So with infra, post: <cit><quote lang="la">haud multum infra viam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:37:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 37, 7</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:98:7:section=20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 98, 7, § 20</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">haud multum post mortem ejus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:5:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 5, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut multum,</quote> <trans><tr>at most</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:10:11:6" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 10, 11, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Vop.</author> Aur. 46</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n29945.8" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">multō</orth> <hi rend="ital">by much, much, a great deal, far, by far</hi> (class.). </sense><sense id="n29945.9" n="1" level="3"> With comparatives and verbs which imply comparison: <cit><quote lang="la">multo tanto carior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:2:3:76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 2, 3, 76</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pauciores oratores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:3:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 3, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">facilius atque expeditius iter,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 6</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">verbs</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">virtutem omnibus rebus multo anteponentes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:4:18:49" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 4, 18, 49</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">multo ceteros anteibant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 4, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">multo praestat beneficii, quam maleficii immemorem esse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 31:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 31, 28</bibl></cit>.—With malle: <cit><quote lang="la">multo mavolo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:1:2:88" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 1, 2, 88</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:2:4:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ps. 2, 4, 38</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">meo judicio multo stare malo, quam, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:12:21:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 12, 21, 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n29945.10" n="2" level="3"> With <hi rend="ital">sup.</hi> (rare but class.), <hi rend="ital">by far, by much</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae tibi mulier videtur multo sapientissuma,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:1:2:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Stich. 1, 2, 66</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:2:2:150" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Am. 2, 2, 150</bibl>: multo optimus hostis, <hi rend="ital">by far</hi>, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 4, 413</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">simulacrum multo antiquissimum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:49:section=109" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 49, § 109</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">2, 4, 23, § 50</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:4:8:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 4, 8, 17</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">maxima pars,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:18:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Imp. Pomp. 18, 54</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:3:82" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 3, 82</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">multo id bellum maximum fuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:11:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 11, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pars multo maxima,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:18:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 30, 18, 14</bibl></cit>: multo molestissima, Cic. Div. in. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0013,001:11:36" default="NO"><author>Caecil.</author> 11, 36</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">multo gratissima lux,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:5:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 5, 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">foedissimum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:4:72" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 9, 4, 72</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">optimum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:ib. 26" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pulcherrimum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:2:24" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 1, 2, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">utilissima,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:10:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 2, 10, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">maxime,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Her.</author> 4, 44, 58</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">multo maxime miserabile,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 36:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 36, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">multo maxime ingenio validus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 6:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> J. 6, 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n29945.11" n="3" level="3"> With particles denoting a difference, <hi rend="ital">far, greatly, very</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">multo aliter,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:prol. 4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. prol. 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">multo aliter ac sperabat,</quote> <trans><tr>far otherwise than</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,022:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Ham. 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod non multo secus fieret, si,</quote> <trans><tr>not far otherwise, not very different</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:4:9:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 4, 9, 1</bibl></cit>: multo infra Cyrenaicum. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:19:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 19, 3, 15, § 40</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n29945.12" n="4" level="3"> In specifications of time, before ante and post, <hi rend="ital">long, much</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">non multo ante urbem captam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:45:101" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 45, 101</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non multo ante,</quote> <trans><tr>not long before</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,018:3:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Eum. 3, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">multo ante,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:4:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 4, 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non multo post, quam, etc.,</quote> <trans><tr>not long after</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:12:49:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 12, 49, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haud multo ante solis occasum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:39:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 39, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">multo ante noctem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:42:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 27, 42, 13</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n29945.13" n="5" level="3"> Very rarely with the positive for multum: <cit><quote lang="la">maligna multo,</quote> <trans><tr>very</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:1:2:83" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 1, 2, 83</bibl></cit> Umpf.— </sense><sense id="n29945.14" n="6" level="3"> Doubled, multo multoque, with comparatives: <cit><quote lang="la">multo multoque longior,</quote> <trans><tr>far, very much</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1245,001:ad M. Caes. 2:5" default="NO"><author>Front.</author> ad M. Caes. 2, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">multo multoque operosius est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:4:1:2" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 4, 1, 2</bibl></cit>: multo multoque magis, Front. Laud. Negl. § 3.</sense><sense id="n29945.15" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">plūs</orth>, plūris; in the <number>plur.</number>, plūres, plūra (in <number>sing.</number> anciently written plous; three times in the S. C. de Bacch. Here perh. belongs, in the <number>plur.</number>, pleores and pleoris, for plures, in the Song of the Arval Brothers.—For the class. neuter of the <number>plur.</number>, plura, the form pluria was used in ante-class. Latinity. Gellius cites M. Cato, Q. Claudius, Valerius Antias, L. Ælius, P. Nigidius, and M. Varro as authorities for this form, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:5:21:6" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 5, 21, 6</bibl>; yet Plautus and Terence have only plura; and the earlier reading pluria, in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:877" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 877</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:1135" default="NO" valid="yes">2, 1135</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:1085" default="NO" valid="yes">4, 1085</bibl>, is now supplanted by the critically certain plura and plurima.—The <hi rend="ital">gen. plur.</hi> plurium, however, has remained the predominant form, e. g. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:7:1:1" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 7, 1, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:4:27" default="NO">8, 4, 27</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:4:66" default="NO">9, 4, 66</bibl> et saep.) [from the root ple; Gr. <foreign lang="greek">ple/on, pi/mplhmi</foreign>; cf. plenus, plera, compleo, etc.; also locu-ples, plebes, populus, etc.], <hi rend="ital">more.</hi> </sense><sense id="n29945.16" n="A" level="2"> In the <number>sing.</number> (used both substantively and adverbially): LIBRAS FARRIS ENDO DIES DATO. SI VOLET PLVS DATO, Fragm. XII. Tab. in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:20:1:45" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 20, 1, 45</bibl>: SI PLVS MINVSVE SECVERVNT, SE FRAVDE ESTO, ib.; <cit><quote lang="la">so (perh. in imitation of this legal phrase): ebeu, cur ego plus minusve feci quam aequom fuit!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:5:3:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 5, 3, 18</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:3:3:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 3, 3, 21</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne plus minusve loqueretur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:84" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 84</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:4:2:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 4, 2, 27</bibl>; and in the signif. of circiter, <hi rend="ital">about</hi>: septingenti sunt paulo plus aut minus anni ... postquam, etc., Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:1:2" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 1, 2</bibl> (Ann. v. 493 Vahl.); <cit><quote lang="la">so. non longius abesse plus minus octo milibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0530,001:B. G. 8:20:1" default="NO"><author>Hirt.</author> B. G. 8, 20, 1</bibl></cit> Oud.; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">speranti plures ... venerunt plusve minusve duae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:8:71:4" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 8, 71, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aut ne quid faciam plus, quod post me minus fecisse satius sit,</quote> <trans><tr>too much ... too little</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:5:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 5, 1, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tantum et plus etiam ipse mihi deberet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:3:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 7, 3, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vos et decem numero, et, quod plus est, Romani estis,</quote> <trans><tr>and what is more</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:24:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 9, 24, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">verbane plus an sententia valere debeat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,042:25:96" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Top. 25, 96</bibl></cit>: <pb n="1174" /> <cb n="MULT" /> cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">apud me argumenta plus quam testes valent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:38:59" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 1, 38, 59</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">valet enim salus plus quam libido,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 40, 63</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n29945.17" n="(b)" level="5"> With a partitive <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">vultis pecuniae plus habere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:1:47:88" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Inv. 1, 47, 88</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">nostri casus plus honoris habuerunt quam laboris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:4:7" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 1, 4, 7</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">plus virium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:1:2:6" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 1, 2, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">plus hostium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">plus dapis et rixae multo minus invidiaeque,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 17, 51</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in hac causā eo plus auctoritatis habent, quia, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:3:16:26" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 3, 16, 26</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">plus ingenii,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 14, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Albano non plus animi erat quam fidei,</quote> <trans><tr>as little courage as fidelity</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:27:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 27, 5</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n29945.18" n="(g)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">quam</hi> (some examples of which have already been given above): <cit><quote lang="la">non plus quam semel,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:15:61" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 15, 61</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">confiteor eos ... plus quam sicarios esse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:13:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 2, 13, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne plus reddat quam acceperit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:16:58" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Lael. 16, 58</bibl></cit> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">non plus quam in tres partis posse distribui putaverunt,</quote> <trans><tr>into not more than</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:1:34:57" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Inv. 1, 34, 57</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">plus quam decem dies abesse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:13:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 2, 13, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nulla (navis) plus quam triginta remis agatur,</quote> <trans><tr>with more than</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:38:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 38, 38, 8</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n29945.19" n="(d)" level="5"> Without <hi rend="ital">quam</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">HOMINES PLOVS V. OINVORSEI VIREI ATQVE MVLIERES, S. C. de Bacch. 19 (Wordsw. Fragm. and Spec. p. 173): plus mille capti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 24, 44</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">plus milies audivi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:3:1:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 3, 1, 32</bibl></cit>: plus semel, Varr. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:14:96" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 14, 14, 17, § 96</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">plus quingentos colaphos infregit mihi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:2:1:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 2, 1, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ferre plus dimidiati mensis cibaria,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:16:37" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 16, 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non plus mille quingentos aeris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:2:22:40" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 2, 22, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">paulo plus ducentos passus a castris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:31:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 31, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum plus annum aeger fuisset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 40, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">parte plus dimidiā rem auctam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:29:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 29, 25</bibl></cit>.—（<foreign lang="greek">e</foreign>) With a compar. or adverbial <case>abl.</case>, or with an <case>abl.</case> of measure: <cit><quote lang="la">VIREI PLOVS DVOBVS, S. C. de Bacch. 20 (Wordsw. Fragm. and Spec. p. 173): de paupertate tacentes Plus poscente ferent,</quote> <trans><tr>more than the importunate</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 17, 44</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex his alius alio plus habet virium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:1:2:6" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 1, 2, 6</bibl></cit>: cave putes hoc tempore plus me quemquam cruciari, Balb. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:8:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 8, 15</bibl>, A, 2: <cit><quote lang="la">alterum certe non potest, ut plus una vera sit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:2:5" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 2, 5</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">in columbā plures videri colores, nec esse plus uno,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 25, 79</bibl></cit>: HOC PLVS NE FACITO, <hi rend="ital">more than this</hi>, Fragm. XII. Tab. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:23:59" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 2, 23, 59</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">annos sexaginta natus es Aut plus eo,</quote> <trans><tr>or more than that</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:1:1:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 1, 1, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">plus aequo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:16:58" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Lael. 16, 58</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">plus paulo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:2:1:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 2, 1, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">paulo plus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:31:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 31, 34</bibl></cit>: multo plus, Anton. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:10:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 10, 8</bibl>, A, 1: <cit><quote lang="la">plus nimio,</quote> <trans><tr>overmuch</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 10, 30</bibl></cit>: quam molestum est uno digito plus habere, <hi rend="ital">too much by a finger</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">a finger too much</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:35:99" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 35, 99</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">uno plus Etruscorum cecidisse in acie,</quote> <trans><tr>one man more</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:7:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 7, 2</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n29945.20" n="2" level="3"> In the <hi rend="ital">gen. pretii</hi>, pluris, <hi rend="ital">of more value, of a higher price, for more, higher, dearer</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut plus reddant musti et olei, et pretii pluris,</quote> <trans><tr>of greater value</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:7:4" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 7, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ager multo pluris est,</quote> <trans><tr>is worth much more</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,003:12:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Com. 12, 33</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">quo pluris sint nostra oliveta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:3:9:16" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 3, 9, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pluris emere,</quote> <trans><tr>dearer</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 7, 2, 1</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">vendere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:12:51" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 3, 12, 51</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:19:section=48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 19, § 48</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:3:300" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 3, 300</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aedificare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:1:4:7" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 1, 4, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pluris est oculatus testis quam auriti decem,</quote> <trans><tr>of more value</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:2:6:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 2, 6, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mea mihi conscientia pluris est, quam omnium sermo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:12:28:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 12, 28, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">facio pluris omnium hominem neminem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 8, 2, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">facere aliquem pluris,</quote> <trans><tr>make more of one, esteem him more highly</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:4:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 3, 4, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pluris habere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:6:4:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 6, 4, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aestimare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,047:6:2:48" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Par. 6, 2, 48</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ducere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:3:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 7, 3, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">putare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:4:18" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 3, 4, 18</bibl></cit> et saep.—</sense><sense id="n29945.21" n="3" level="3"> Rarely, instead of the genitive, in the <hi rend="ital">abl. pretii</hi>: plure vendunt, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> 2, p. 189</bibl> P.: plure altero tanto, quanto ejus fundus est, velim, Plaut. ib.: plure venit, Cic. ib.—</sense><sense id="n29945.22" n="4" level="3"> Plus plusque, <hi rend="ital">more and more</hi>: quem mehercule plus plusque in dies diligo. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:6:2:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 6, 2, 10</bibl>.—* </sense><sense id="n29945.23" n="5" level="3"> Like magis, with an <pos>adj.</pos>: <cit><quote lang="la">plus formosus, for formosior,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Nemes.</author> Ecl. 4, 72</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n29945.24" n="B" level="2"> In the <number>plur.</number> </sense><sense id="n29945.25" n="1" level="3"> Comparatively, <hi rend="ital">more</hi> in number: <cit><quote lang="la">omnes qui aere alieno premantur, quos plures esse intellego quam putāram,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:3:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 7, 3, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:2:22:40" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 2, 22, 40</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nemini ego plura acerba esse credo ex amore homini umquam oblata quam mihi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:3:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 3, 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne plura insignia essent imperii in libero populo quam in regno fuissent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:2:31:55" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 2, 31, 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">multo plura,</quote> <trans><tr>many more things</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:3:6:28" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 3, 6, 28</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n29945.26" n="2" level="3"> In gen., of a great number, <hi rend="ital">many</hi>: qui plus fore dicant in pluribus consilii quam in uno. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:35:55" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 1, 35, 55</bibl>: cf.: <cb n="MULT" /> quid quaeso interest inter unum et plures, si justitia est in pluribus? <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 39, 61</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">1, 34, 52: non possunt unā in civitate multi rem ac fortunas amittere, ut non plures secum in eandem trahant calamitatem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:7:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Imp. Pomp. 7, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod pluribus praesentibus eas res jactari nolebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">plura castella Pompeius tentaverat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. C. 3, 52</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">summus dolor plures dies manere non potest,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:28:93" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2, 28, 93</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pluribus diebus, Quint. prooem. § 7: illic plurium rerum est congeries,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> 8, 4, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae consuetudo sit, pluribus verbis docere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:41:115" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 41, 115</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">eum pluribus verbis rogat, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:28:section=64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 28, § 64</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">without verba: quid ego plura dicam?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:5:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 5, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pluribus haec exsecutus sum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0975,001:3:10:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Phaedr.</author> 3, 10, 59</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">also elliptically, quid plura? and, ne plura, like quid multa? and ne multa: hic sacra, hic genus, hic majorum multa vestigia. Quid plura? hanc vides villam, etc.,</quote> <trans><tr>what need of many words? in short</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:1:3" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 2, 1, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sed—ne plura—dicendum enim aliquando est—Pomponium Atticum sic amo, ut alterum fratrem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:13:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 13, 1, 5</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n29945.27" n="b" level="4"> Esp.: plures. </sense><sense id="n29945.28" n="(a)" level="5"> <hi rend="ital">The mass, the multitude</hi>, opp. pauciores, = <foreign lang="greek">oi( o)li/goi</foreign>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:1:1:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 1, 1, 13</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n29945.29" n="(b)" level="5"> Euphemistically, acc. to the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">oi( plei/ones</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">the dead</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quin prius Me ad plures penetravi?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:2:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 2, 2, 14</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n29945.30" n="(g)" level="5"> <hi rend="ital">The greater number, the majority</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">plures nesciebant quā ex causā convenissent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:19:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Act. 19, 32</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n29945.31" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">plūrĭmus</orth> (archaic form, plisima plurima, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=204" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 204</bibl> and 205 Müll.: PLIOIRVME (I), Epit. of Scipio), a, um [from root ple; whence also plus, q. v., ploirumus for ploisumus; and thence the predominant form plurimus], <hi rend="ital">most, very much</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">many</hi> (as an <pos>adj.</pos> in good prose mostly in the <number>plur.</number>, except the standing formula of greeting: salutem plurimam dicere alicui; <xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">infra</ref></xr>): <cit><quote lang="la">hujus sunt plurima simulacra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:6:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 6, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nos plurimis ignotissimi gentibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:17:26" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 1, 17, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">plurimae et maximae partes,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 4, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">plurimorum seculorum memoria,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 9, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec plurimis a me verbis dicta sunt,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 7, 12</bibl></cit> et saep.—In <number>sing.</number>: <cit><quote lang="la">me plurimā praedā onustum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:4:2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 4, 2, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sermo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:2:5" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 2, 2, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">risus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:6:3:85" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 6, 3, 85</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">res,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:6:1:51" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 6, 1, 51</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">exercitatio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 8</bibl></cit> prooem. § <cit><quote lang="la">28: mons,</quote> <trans><tr>very large</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:419" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 419</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cervix,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 3, 52</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aetna,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:600" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Ib. 600</bibl></cit>.—Of a greeting: impertit salutem plurimam, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 472</bibl>. 16; and esp. freq.: salutem plurimam dicit (commonly abbrev. S. P. D.) at the beginning of letters; v. salus.— <usg type="style">Poet.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">medio cum plurimus orbe Sol erat,</quote> <trans><tr>very powerful, oppressive</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 53</bibl></cit>: plurima quā silva est. <hi rend="ital">thickest</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:14:361" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 14, 361</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">coma plurima,</quote> <trans><tr>very thick</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:13:844" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 13, 844</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sed plurima nantis in ore Alcyone conjux,</quote> <trans><tr>mostly, chiefly</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:11:562" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 11, 562</bibl></cit>.—And collect.: <cit><quote lang="la">plurimus in Junonis honorem Aptum dicet equis Argos,</quote> <trans><tr>many a one, very many</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:7:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 7, 8</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">oleaster plurimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:183" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 183</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quā plurima mittitur ales,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:9:56:1" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 9, 56, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">plurima lecta rosa est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:4:441" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 4, 441</bibl></cit>.— In <hi rend="ital">neutr. absol.</hi> (substant. or adverb.): <cit><quote lang="la">ut haberet quam plurimum,</quote> <trans><tr>as much as possible</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,030:14:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rab. Post. 14, 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">caput autem est, quam plurimum scribere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:33:150" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 33, 150</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut in quoque oratore plurimum esset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:27:123" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 1, 27, 123</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">plūrĭmum</orth>: <cit><quote lang="la">et is valebat in suffragio plurimum, cujus plurimum intererat, esse in optimo statu civitatem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:2:22:40" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 2, 22, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">auspiciis plurimum obsecutus est Romulus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 9, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si vero populus plurimum potest,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 14, 23</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">qui apud me dignitate plurimum possunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 1, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">plurimum aliis praestare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:2:1:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Inv. 2, 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut te plurimum diligam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:1:7:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 1, 7, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:27:78" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 5, 27, 78</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">hoc ego utor uno omnium plurimum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:11:16:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 11, 16, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quantum (al. quanto) plurimum possunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:11:3:120" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 11, 3, 120</bibl></cit>: plurimum quantum also signifies <hi rend="ital">very much indeed, exceedingly</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">plurimum quantum veritati nocuere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Min. Fel.</author> Oct. 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">gratulor,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(elleborum) ex aquā datur plurimum drachma,</quote> <trans><tr>at the most</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:25:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 25, 5, 22, § 54</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:125" default="NO" valid="yes">9, 36, 60, § 125</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:30:48" default="NO" valid="yes">30, 6, 16, § 48</bibl>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">cum plurimum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:78" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 17, 15, § 78</bibl></cit> (opp. to cum minimum); 18, 7, 10, § 60: nec tam numerosa differentia; tribus ut plurimum bonitatibus distat, <hi rend="ital">for the most part, commonly, usually</hi>, = plerumque, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 3, 4, § 18</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n29945.32" n="(b)" level="5"> In <hi rend="ital">neutr.</hi> with a partit. <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>: sententiarum et gravitatis plurimum, Cic. Inv. <cb n="MUND" /> 1, 18, 25: <cit><quote lang="la">artis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:5:3" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 10, 5, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">auctoritatis et ponderis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:4:91" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 9, 4, 91</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut laboris sic utilitatis etiam longe plurimum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:3:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 10, 3, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">virtutum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:1:20" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 12, 1, 20</bibl></cit> plurimum quantum favoris partibus dabat fratermtas ducum, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:4:2:74" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 4, 2, 74</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n29945.33" n="(g)" level="5"> In the <hi rend="ital">gen. pretii</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">plurimi: immo unice unum plurimi pendit,</quote> <trans><tr>values very highly, esteems very much</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:2:2:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 2, 2, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quem unum Alexander plurimi fecerat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,018:2:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Eum. 2, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut quisque quod plurimi est possidet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,047:6:2:48" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Par. 6, 2, 48</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
mulucha: <entryFree id="n29946" type="main" key="Mulucha"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mulucha</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> and <gen>f.</gen> <sense id="n29946.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Masc., a river in Africa, between Mauritania and Numidia</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Maluja</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 19:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 19, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:92:5" default="NO" valid="yes">92, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:110:8" default="NO" valid="yes">110, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:5:1:5" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 5, 1, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 2, 1, § 35</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n29946.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Fem., a city on this river</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:3:1:14" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 3, 1, 14</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
mulus: <entryFree id="n29947" type="main" key="mu_lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mūlus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>perh. mu-; Gr. <foreign lang="greek">muka/w</foreign>; cf. <foreign lang="greek">mu/klos</foreign>, an ass</etym>, <sense id="n29947.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a mule</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">muli pretio qui superant equos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:3:5:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 3, 5, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rhedarii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:17" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">clitellarius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,042:8:35" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Top. 8, 35</bibl></cit>: mulus vehiculo lunae habetur, quod tam ea sterilis sit quam mulus; vel quod, ut mulus non suo genere sed equis creatur, sic ea solis, non suo fulgore luceat, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=148" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 148</bibl> Müll.: mulis celebrantur ludi in Circo Maximo Consualibus, quia id genus quadrupedum primum putatur coeptum currui vehiculoque adjungi, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=148" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 148</bibl> ib.—As a term of abuse, <hi rend="ital">you mule, you ass</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">mule, nihil sentis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:83:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 83, 3</bibl></cit>: muli Mariani, <hi rend="ital">Marius's mules</hi>, a nickname given to the soldiers of C. Marius, because they were compelled to carry their baggage on their backs like mules, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1245,001:Strat. 4:1:7" default="NO"><author>Front.</author> Strat. 4, 1, 7</bibl>; Paul. ex Fest. s. v. muli, p. 149 Müll.; and s. v. aerumnulas, p. 24 ib.— Prov: mutuum muli scabunt, like the Engl. <hi rend="ital">you claw me, and I'll claw you</hi>, of those who flatter one another, <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Idyll. 12</bibl>; hence: ridiculum est, cum te Cascam tua dicit amica, Fili Potoni, sesquisenex puerum. Dice illam pusam: sic fiet mutua muli, Poët. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 7:section=28" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 7, § 28</bibl> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">mulum de asino pingere, a proverbial expression made use of when the original and the copy differ but little from each other, or when absurdities are represented by absurdities, or lies concealed with lies,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Val. 19 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
mulvianus: <entryFree id="n29948" type="main" key="Mulvi^a_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mulvĭānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>Mulvius</etym>, <sense id="n29948.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to a Mulvius, Mulvian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">controversia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:15:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 2, 15, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">colonia,</quote> <trans><tr>named after a Mulvius</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 11, 10, § 38</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
mulvius: <entryFree id="n29949" type="main" key="Mulvi^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mulvĭus</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Milvius</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <sense id="n29949.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adj., Mulvian</hi> (<hi rend="ital">Milvian</hi>): Mulvius pons, <hi rend="ital">a bridge across the Tiber, above Rome, on the</hi> Via Flaminia, now <hi rend="ital">Ponte Molle, near Torretta</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:13:33:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 13, 33, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:3:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 3, 2, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:3:23:6" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 3, 23, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:3:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 3, 47</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Milvius agger, i. e. pons,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:2:1:176" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 2, 1, 176</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 45:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 45, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
mummia: <entryFree id="n29950" type="main" key="Mummia"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mummia</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, v. Mummius.</entryFree>
mummius: <entryFree id="n29951" type="main" key="Mummi^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mummĭus</orth>, <itype>a</itype>, <sense id="n29951.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">name of a Roman</hi> gens. The most celebrated are, </sense><sense id="n29951.1" n="1" level="3"> L. Mummius Achaicus, <hi rend="ital">the destroyer of Corinth</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:22:76" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 22, 76</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:21:section=55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 21, § 55</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 3, 4, § 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:1:13:1" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 1, 13, 1</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n29951.2" n="2" level="3"> His brother, Sp. Mummius, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:12:18" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 1, 12, 18</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 34, 46</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 9, 16</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:13:5:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 13, 5, 11</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n29951.3" n="3" level="3"> Another Mummius, <hi rend="ital">a composer of Atellane plays</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 118</bibl> P.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 10, 9, p. 514</bibl> Krehl.—In <hi rend="ital">fem.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Mummia</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <hi rend="ital">wife of the emperor Galba</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=gal.:3" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Galb. 3</bibl>.—Hence, ‡ <orth extent="full" lang="la">Mummiānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj., of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to Mummius, Mummian</hi>: aedificia, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=140" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 140</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
munatius: <entryFree id="n29952" type="main" key="Muna_ti^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Munātĭus</orth>, <itype>a</itype>, <sense id="n29952.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">name of a Roman</hi> gens. So, </sense><sense id="n29952.1" n="1" level="3"> Cn. Munatius Plancus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:10:6:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 10, 6, 1</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">17, 2, 21 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n29952.2" n="2" level="3"> L. Munatius Plancus, <hi rend="ital">a lieutenant of Cæsar, brother of the preceding</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:24:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 24, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:40:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. C. 1, 40, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:3:15:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 3, 15, 38</bibl>. For his letters to Cicero, and Cicero's letters to him, v. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:10:1 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 10, 1 sq.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n29952.3" n="3" level="3"> T. Munatius Plancus Bursa, <hi rend="ital">ridiculed for his ignorance</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:10:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 9, 10, 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">7, 2, 2</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n29952.4" n="4" level="3"> Another T. Munatius Plancus, <hi rend="ital">a friend and kinsman of</hi> 2. supra, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:10:12:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 10, 12, 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">10, 12, 5</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
munctio: <entryFree id="n29953" type="main" key="muncti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">munctĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>mungo</etym>, <sense id="n29953.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a blowing of the nose</hi> (eccl. Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">munctiones muculentae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 3, 107</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
munda: <entryFree id="n29954" type="main" key="Munda"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Munda</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <sense id="n29954.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A city in</hi> Hispania Baetica, <hi rend="ital">taken by Cœsar in the war against the son of Pompey</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Monda</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:42:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 24, 42, 1</bibl>; Auct. B. Hisp. 32; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:7:6:5" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 7, 6, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:3:100" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 3, 100</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:4:2:85" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 4, 2, 85</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n29954.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A river in Lusitania, between the Tagus and the Douro</hi>, <pb n="1175" /> <cb n="MUND" /> now <hi rend="ital">Mondego</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:115" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 21, 35, § 115</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">also called Monda,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:3:1:7" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 3, 1, 7</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
mundanus: <entryFree id="n29955" type="main" key="munda_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mundānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>2. mundus</etym>, <sense id="n29955.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to the world, mundane</hi>. </sense><sense id="n29955.1" n="I" level="1"> <pos>Adj.</pos> (late Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">anima mundana,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> Somn. Scip. 2, 16</bibl></cit>: annus, <hi rend="ital">a year of the world, mundane year</hi>, consisting of fifteen thousand years, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 11</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ora, i. e. caelestis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Avien.</author> Arat. 216</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n29955.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">mun-dānus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">an inhabitant of the world, a cosmopolite</hi>, as translation of <foreign lang="greek">ko/smos</foreign>, = mundi incola et civis, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:37:108" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 37, 108</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
mundatio: <entryFree id="n29956" type="main" key="munda_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mundātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>mundo</etym>, <sense id="n29956.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a cleansing</hi> (eccl. Lat.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Conf. 1:11" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Conf. 1, 11</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Theod. Prisc.</author> 1, 19</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
mundator: <entryFree id="n29957" type="main" key="munda_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mundātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n29957.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a cleanser</hi> (post-class.): cloacarum, Firm. Math. 8, 19 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
mundatorius: <entryFree id="n29958" type="hapax" key="munda_to_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mundātōrĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>mundator</etym>, <sense id="n29958.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to cleansing, mundatory</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">medicamentum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Plin. Val.</author> 2, 25</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
mundatus: <entryFree id="n29959" type="main" key="munda_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mundātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood>; and <pos>P. a.</pos>, v. mundo <sense id="n29959.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
mundatrix: <entryFree id="n29960" type="main" key="munda_trix"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mundātrix</orth>, <itype>ĭcis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>mundator</etym>, <sense id="n29960.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a cleaner</hi> (late Lat.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:in Psa. 142:8" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> in Psa. 142, 8</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
munde: <entryFree id="n29961" type="main" key="munde_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mundē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. 1. mundus <sense id="n29961.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
mundensis: <entryFree id="n29962" type="main" key="Mundensis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mundensis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>Munda</etym>, <sense id="n29962.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to Munda</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">duces, Auct. B. Hisp. 36: proelium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:56" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 56</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
mundialis: <entryFree id="n29963" type="main" key="mundi^a_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mundĭālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>2. mundus</etym>, <sense id="n29963.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">worldly, mundane</hi> (eccl. Lat.). elementa, <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Spect. 9</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sordes,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Anim. 54</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">negotia,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hier.</author> Ep. 43, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">historici,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Sulp.</author> Sev. Chron. 2, 14, 6</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <pos>adv.</pos>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">mundĭālĭter</orth>, <hi rend="ital">in the manner of the world</hi> (eccl. Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">vivere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Res. Carn. 46</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
mundicina: <entryFree id="n29964" type="main" key="mundi^ci_na"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mundĭcīna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>1. mundus</etym>, <sense id="n29964.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a means of cleansing</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">dentium,</quote> <trans><tr>toothpowder</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Mag. p. 277, 4</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
mundicors: <entryFree id="n29965" type="main" key="mundi^cors"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mundĭ-cors</orth>, <itype>dis</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>1. mundus-cor</etym>, <sense id="n29965.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">clean-hearted</hi> (eccl. Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">beati mundicordes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Serm. 53" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Serm. 53</bibl></cit> de Verb. Evang.</sense></entryFree>
mundifico: <entryFree id="n29966" type="main" key="mundi^fi^co"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mundĭfĭco</orth>, <itype>1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>1. mundus-facio</etym>, <sense id="n29966.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to make clean, to cleanse</hi>: stomachum, Macer. 3, 12.—<usg type="style">Transf.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">se caelesti conversatione,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cassiod.</author> de Anim. 11</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
mundiger: <entryFree id="n29967" type="hapax" key="mundi^ger"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mundĭger</orth>, <itype>ĕra, ĕrum</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>2. mundus-gero</etym>, <sense id="n29967.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">world-bearing, that sustains the world</hi>: axis, Poët. ap. Anth. Lat. t. 1, p. 16 Burm.</sense></entryFree>
mundipotens: <entryFree id="n29968" type="main" key="mundi^po^tens"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mundĭ-pŏtens</orth>, <itype>tis</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>2. munduspotens</etym>, <sense id="n29968.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">world-ruling, that rules the world</hi> (eccl. Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">potestates,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Anim. 23</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
munditenens: <entryFree id="n29969" type="main" key="mundi^te^nens"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mundĭ-tĕnens</orth>, <itype>tis</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>2. mundustenens</etym>, <sense id="n29969.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that holds</hi> or <hi rend="ital">rules the world</hi> (eccl. Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">diabolus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Val. 22</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
munditer: <entryFree id="n29970" type="main" key="mundi^ter"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mundĭter</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. 1. mundus <sense id="n29970.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
munditia: <entryFree id="n29971" type="main" key="mundi^ti^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mundĭtĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, and <orth extent="full" lang="la">mundĭtĭes</orth>, <itype>ēi</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>1. mundus</etym>, <sense id="n29971.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">cleanness, cleanliness</hi> (class.; cf.: ornatus, cultus). </sense><sense id="n29971.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">munditia illecebra animo est amantium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:2:3:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 2, 3, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">munditias facere,</quote> <trans><tr>to clean the house</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 39, 2</bibl></cit>: munditias volo fieri; <cit><quote lang="la">ecferte huc scopas, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:2:2:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Stich. 2, 2, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alia jam munditiarum facies est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1245,001:Aq. 88" default="NO"><author>Front.</author> Aq. 88</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n29971.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, in gen., <hi rend="ital">cleanliness, neatness, elegance, fineness, niceness</hi>, in furniture, dress, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">in munditiis aetatulam agere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:2:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 1, 2, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">munditiis munditiam antideo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:2:3:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cas. 2, 3, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">munditia non odiosa neque exquisita nimis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:36:130" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 36, 130</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hominis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:10:20:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 10, 20, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cui flavam religas comam, Simplex munditiis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:5:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 5, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">munditiis capimur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:3:133" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 3, 133</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">urbanae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 63:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 63, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">per cultum et munditias,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:3:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 3, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">multa munditia indutus et amictus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:2:5:2" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 2, 5, 2</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n29971.3" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, of speech, <hi rend="ital">neatness, terseness, elegance</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:23:79" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 23, 79</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">verborum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:1:23:1" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 1, 23, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">venustas et mundities orationis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:10:3:4" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 10, 3, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:3:87" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 8, 3, 87</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
mundivagus: <entryFree id="n29972" type="main" key="mundi^va^gus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mundĭvăgus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>mundusvagus</etym>, <sense id="n29972.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">wandering in the world</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Grut.</author> p. 1174</bibl>; Epigr. 8, 13.</sense></entryFree>
mundo: <entryFree id="n29973" type="main" key="mundo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mundo</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>1. mundus</etym>, <sense id="n29973.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to make clean, to clean, cleanse</hi> (post-Aug.; <cit><quote lang="la">syn.: purgo, emendo): mundatur nitro,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:33:103" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 33, 6, 34, § 103</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praesepia mundanda curare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:12:3" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 12, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">perlui et mundari,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Mamert.</author> Grat. Act. 9 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n29973.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> (eccl. Lat.), <hi rend="ital">to cleanse, make clean</hi>. </sense><sense id="n29973.2" n="1" level="3"> Ceremonially, according to the Levitical law of uncleanness: <cit><quote lang="la">et purificabis eos (sc. Levitas),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,004:8:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Num. 8, 6</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n29973.3" n="2" level="3"> Spiritually, from sin: <cit><quote lang="la">ab occultis meis munda me,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,027:19:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Psa. 19, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mundemus nos ab omni inquinamento earnis et spiritūs,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,008:7:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2 Cor. 7, 1</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <cb n="MUND" /> <orth extent="full" lang="la">mundātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">P. a., cleansed, clean</hi> (late Lat.); in <hi rend="ital">comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quam sim ab illā peste mundatior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Conf. 10:37" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Conf. 10, 37</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
mundule: <entryFree id="n29974" type="main" key="mundu^le_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mundŭlē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. mundulus <sense id="n29974.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
mundulus: <entryFree id="n29975" type="main" key="mundu^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mundŭlus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <sense id="n29975.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adj. dim.</hi> [1. mundus], <hi rend="ital">cleanly, neat, trim, nice, spruce</hi> (anteclass.): <cit><quote lang="la">amasii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:3:1:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 3, 1, 13</bibl></cit>.— <itype>Hence</itype>, <pos>adv.</pos>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">mundŭlē</orth>, <hi rend="ital">neatly, trimly, nicely</hi> (post-class.): qui ubi ad Dircaeum fontem adveniunt, mundule nitidantur jugulos quadripedantum, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 144, 17</bibl> (Trag. Rel. v. 602 Rib.): <cit><quote lang="la">mundule amicta,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 2, p. 117, 33</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
mundum: <entryFree id="n29976" type="main" key="mundum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mundum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, v. 2. mundus <sense id="n29976.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">init.</hi></sense></entryFree>
mundus: <entryFree id="n29977" type="main" key="mundus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mundus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>Sanscr. mund, purificari</etym>, <sense id="n29977.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">clean, cleanly, nice, neat, elegant</hi>. </sense><sense id="n29977.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> (class.; <cit><quote lang="la">syn.: lautus, nitidus, purus): supellex,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 5, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">caena,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:29:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> C. 3, 29, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ager,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:19:12:8" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 19, 12, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mundissimum cubile desiderat (animal),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:7:9:14" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 7, 9, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jam intus mundissimumst,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:2:7:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 2, 7, 7</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, with <case>abl.</case>, = ornatus: Ostia munita est: idem loca navibus pulchris Munda facit, <hi rend="ital">adorned</hi>, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> p. 258</bibl> Müll. (Ann. v. 146 Vahl.).— </sense><sense id="n29977.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n29977.3" n="1" level="3"> Of mode of living, <hi rend="ital">neat, fine, elegant, smart, genteel</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cultus justo mundior,</quote> <trans><tr>too elegant dress</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 15</bibl></cit>.— As <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">mundus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> (sc. homo), <hi rend="ital">an elegant</hi> or <hi rend="ital">nice person</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:8:23" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2, 8, 23</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n29977.4" n="2" level="3"> Of quality, <hi rend="ital">not coarse, fine</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">annonae, of wheat,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Lampr.</author> Alex. Sev. 42, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">panis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 37, 3</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n29977.5" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg> </sense><sense id="n29977.6" n="A" level="2"> Of speech, <hi rend="ital">neat, fine, elegant</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg> and in postclass. prose): <cit><quote lang="la">verba, Ov A. A. 3, 479: versus, quibus mundius nihil reperiri puto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:19:9:10" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 19, 9, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in Gallos mundius subtiliusque est, quam cum Gallis aut contra Gallos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:17:2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 17, 2 <hi rend="ital">med.</hi></bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n29977.7" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">mun-dum</orth>, i. <gen>n.</gen>, only in the phrase: in mundo (esse or habere), <hi rend="ital">in readiness</hi> (ante-class.): tibi vita seu mors in mundo est, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 181</bibl> P. (Ann. v. 457 Vahl.: <cit><quote lang="la">in mundo pro palam et in expedito ac cito, Charis.): nempe habeo in mundo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:1:1:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Pers. 1, 1, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mihi in mundo sunt virgae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:2:1:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> As. 2, 1, 16</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">2, 2, 50</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nescio quid vero habeo in mundo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:3:2:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Stich. 3, 2, 23</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:5:85" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ps. 1, 5, 85</bibl> Ritschl.—</sense><sense id="n29977.8" n="C" level="2"> In eccl. Lat., <hi rend="ital">morally pure, upright, free from sin</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cor mundum crea in me, Deus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,027:50:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Psa. 50, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">beati mundo corde,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:5:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Matt. 5, 8</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <pos>adv.</pos>, in two forms (both, for the most part, anteand post-class.).—</sense><sense id="n29977.9" n="a" level="4"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">mundē</orth>, <hi rend="ital">cleanly, neatly, prettily</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">(copia) in suo quaeque loco sita munde,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:5:4:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 5, 4, 5</bibl></cit>: verrite aedes, spargite munde, Titin. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 183</bibl> P.: <cit><quote lang="la">parum munde et parum decenter,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 70:20" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 70, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">munde facti versus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:10:17:2" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 10, 17, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quam mundissime purissimeque fiat,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 66, 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n29977.10" n="b" level="4"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">mun-dĭter</orth>, <hi rend="ital">cleanly, neatly</hi>. </sense><sense id="n29977.11" n="1" level="3"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum sedulo munditer nos habeamus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:1:2:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 1, 2, 26</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n29977.12" n="2" level="3"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">decently, with propriety</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">dicere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Mag. p. 296, 14</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n29978" type="main" key="mundus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mundus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> (<sense id="n29978.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">neutr</hi>. collat. form, mundum: legavit quidam uxori mundum omne penumque, <hi rend="ital">all her toilet</hi>, Lucil. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:4:1:3" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 4, 1, 3</bibl>, and ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 214, 17</bibl>) [1. mundus], <hi rend="ital">toilet ornaments, decorations, dress</hi> (of a woman). </sense><sense id="n29978.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">mundus muliebris est, quo mulier mundior fit: continentur eo specula, matulae, unguenta, vasa unguentaria, et si qua similia dici possunt, veluti lavatio, riscus ... Unguenta, quibus valetudinis causā unguimur, mundo non continentur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:34:2:25" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 34, 2, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">munditiae et ornatus et cultus, haec feminarum insignia sunt: hunc mundum muliebrem appellārunt majores nostri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:7:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 34, 7, 9</bibl></cit>: virginalis, Att. ap. Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=142" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 142</bibl> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">quamvis auro, veste, gemmis, omnique cetero mundo exornata mulier incedat,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 2, p. 118</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n29978.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n29978.3" n="A" level="2"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">an implement</hi> (ante- and post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">operae messoriae mundus,</quote> <trans><tr>implements for the harvest work</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 6 <hi rend="ital">init.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Cereris,</quote> <trans><tr>the mystical casket of Ceres</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Mag. p. 282</bibl></cit> (the expression in mundo esse and habere belongs to the <pos>adj.</pos> mundus, v. mundus, II. B.).—</sense><sense id="n29978.4" n="B" level="2"> Like the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">ko/smos</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">the universe, the world</hi>, esp. <hi rend="ital">the heavens and the heavenly bodies</hi>: ut hunc hac varietate distinctum bene Graeci <foreign lang="greek">ko/smon</foreign>, nos lucentem mundum nominaremus, <hi rend="ital">the heavens</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,072:chapter=10" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Univ. 10</bibl>: nam quem <foreign lang="greek">ko/smos</foreign> Graeci, nomine ornamenti appellaverunt. eum nos a perfectā absolutāque elegantiā, mundum, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 4, 3, § 8</bibl>: concussit micantia sidera mundus, <hi rend="ital">heaven shook</hi>, <cb n="MUNE" /> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:64:206" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 64, 206</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aetherius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:3:4:17" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 3, 4, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">arduus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:240" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 240</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aestuat infelix angusto limite mundi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:10:169" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 10, 169</bibl></cit>. Also: mundus caeli, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 6, 2</bibl> (Sat. v. 10, p. 156 Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">o clarissima mundi Lumina,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:5 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 5 sq.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">immensi copia mundi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:157" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 157</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ipse mundus deorum hominumque causā factus est...Est enim mundus quasi communis deorum atque hominum domus, aut urbs utrorumque,</quote> <trans><tr>the world</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:62:154" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 62, 154</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">innumerabiles,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 17, 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">e tabulā pictos ediscere mundos,</quote> <trans><tr>parts of the world</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:5:3:37" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 5, 3, 37</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n29978.5" n="2" level="3"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n29978.6" n="a" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">The world</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">the earth, the inhabitants of the earth, mankind</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">quicumque mundo terminus obstitit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:3:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 3, 53</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">spes miseri mundi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:5:469" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 5, 469</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:3:3:87" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 3, 3, 87</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">fastos evolvere mundi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:3:112" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 3, 112</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mundum laedere,</quote> <trans><tr>mankind</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> Ruf. 1, 87</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nullā in parte mundi cessat ebrietas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:14:149" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 14, 22, 29, § 149</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:30:8" default="NO" valid="yes">30, 1, 2, § 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:2:12:1" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 2, 12, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:30:4:9" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 30, 4, 9</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">(Alexander) scrutatur maria ignota, et, ut ita dicam, mundi claustra perrumpit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 119:7" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 119, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mundi principio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:15:147" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 15, 147</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n29978.7" n="b" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">The heavens</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">the sky, the weather</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">tepida indulget terris clementia mundi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Grat.</author> Fal. 288</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad Eoos tractūs mundique teporem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:8:365" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 8, 365</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n29978.8" n="c" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">The sun</hi> (perh. only in Manilius): <cit><quote lang="la">quā mundus redit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0926,001:1:36" default="NO"><author>Manil.</author> Astron. 1, 36</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 591</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n29978.9" n="d" level="4"> Euphemistically for <hi rend="ital">the Lower World, the infernal regions</hi>. The opening into this mundus was at Rome, in the Comitium, and was kept covered with a stone (lapis manalis); three times in the year, on the 24th of August, the 5th of October, and the 8th of November, days sacred to the gods of the infernal regions, this round pit was opened, and all sorts of fruits were thrown into it as offerings, Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 1, 16, 18</bibl>; Paul. ex Fest. s. v mundus, p. 154 Müll., and s. v. manalem lapidem, p. 128 ib.—</sense><sense id="n29978.10" n="e" level="4"> Esp. (eccl. Lat.), <hi rend="ital">the world</hi> as opposed to <hi rend="ital">the church; this world</hi>, the realm of sin and death, as opposed to <hi rend="ital">Christ's kingdom</hi> of holiness and life: <cit><quote lang="la">non pro mundo rogo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Johan. 17, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">de mundo non sunt,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 17, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">princeps hujus mundi (i. e. Satan),</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 12, 31</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">14, 30: regnum meum non est de hoc mundo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 18, 36</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,010:2:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eph. 2, 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">6, 12</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
